rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;355b90a.1503">   <title>Workshop on The X-Radiography of Cultural Materials </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;355b90a.1503</link>   <description> A workshop entitled The X-Radiography of Cultural Materials will be held<br>in the Conservation Department of the Royal Ontario Museum, May 5th,<br>6th, 7th, 2015. The workshop will be led by the foremost authorities on<br>the radiography of historic materials, Dr. Sonia O\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdConnor and Mr. Tom<br>Sparrow of the Archaeological Sciences department of the University of<br>Bradford, UK. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T17:41:45-04:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Susan Stock</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;355b90a.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;fc608eae.1503">   <title>TAG 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;fc608eae.1503</link>   <description> Dear Colleagues<br><br>Please find below details of TAG 2015 to be held at Bradford University:<br><br>Call for sessions: www.tag2015bradford.org&lt;http://tag2015bradford.org/home/&gt;<br><br>The next TAG will be held at the University of Bradford, 14-16th December 2015.<br><br>The call for sessions is now open. We encourage sessions based on our broad theme of Diversity, however, we are happy to accept proposals outside of the theme. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T14:00:04+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>TAG-Bradford</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;fc608eae.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;b7462f4b.1503">   <title>Conservation Scientist Position at Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, Smithsonian </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;b7462f4b.1503</link>   <description> The Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery is seeking a Conservation Scientist to perform scientific research, as well as identification and analyses of materials used in works of art to support the efforts of the staff in the galleries. The Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery are the Smithsonian Institution’s museums of Asian Art. The two Galleries are co-administered and share the same staff, but maintain separate identities. The collections of the Freer and Sackler Galleries include artworks from the Near East and Southeast Asia, as well as the Far East and the United [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T21:51:29+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>McCarthy, Blythe</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;b7462f4b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;6ef5fd5c.1503">   <title>Re: AW: Roman iron and lead </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;6ef5fd5c.1503</link>   <description> Dear sir,<br><br>Thank you for your response.<br>I already downloaded the paper and I will study the bibliography shortly.<br>ResearchGate is a great source.<br><br>Best regards,<br><br>Peter Seinen<br><br>-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----<br>Van: Arch-Metals Group [mailto:ARCH-METALS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] Namens Amin Emami<br>Verzonden: maandag 2 maart 2015 11:36<br>Aan: ARCH-METALS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Onderwerp: Re: AW: Roman iron and lead<br><br>Dear Peter<br><br>Thermal ionization mass spectrometry (TIMS) and laser ablation ICPMS can help you also to elucidate the possible difference between Medival to New lead artefacts. Important is also lead bearing ores from the territory of ancient workshop. Lead, or Lead-Zinc-Silver paragenesis.<br>Please have a look on the [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T12:21:37+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Peter Seinen</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;6ef5fd5c.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;3272a3f2.1503">   <title>Re: AW: Roman iron and lead </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;3272a3f2.1503</link>   <description> Dear Peter<br><br>Thermal ionization mass spectrometry (TIMS) and laser ablation ICPMS can help you also to elucidate the possible difference between Medival to New lead artefacts. Important is also lead bearing ores from the territory of ancient workshop. Lead, or Lead-Zinc-Silver paragenesis.<br>Please have a look on the bibliography of this paper:<br>&quot;Strontium, lead and zinc isotopes in marine cores as tracers of sedimentary provenance: A case study around Taiwan orogen<br>Chemical Geology 248 (2008) 62\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd82&quot;<br>Yours<br>Assoc. Prof. M-.Amin Emami   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T10:35:48+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Amin Emami</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;3272a3f2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;1045e5c2.1503">   <title>Re: Roman iron and lead </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;1045e5c2.1503</link>   <description> Dear Ernst,<br><br>Thank you for your suggestion. It is certainly worthwhile to make an attempt.<br><br>How should this be done ? I guess you mean a few 100 mg of carbon. How can it the extracted from the iron matrix ? I guess there are a few institutes that are specialized in this type of samples. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T11:14:24+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Peter Seinen</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;1045e5c2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;267c4529.1503">   <title>AW: Roman iron and lead </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;267c4529.1503</link>   <description> You can also try radiocarbon dating, if you can obtain a sample of a few 100 mg.<br><br>Best wishes, Ernst Pernicka<br><br>M: ernst.pernicka@cez-archaeometrie.de<br><br>Von: Arch-Metals Group [mailto:ARCH-METALS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] Im Auftrag von Peter Seinen<br>Gesendet: Montag, 2. M\ufffd\ufffdrz 2015 10:31<br>An: ARCH-METALS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Betreff: Re: Roman iron and lead<br><br>Dear sir,<br><br>Thank you for your quick response.<br><br>I guess making a distinction between ancient and modern materials is doable. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T10:47:13+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ernst Pernicka</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;267c4529.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;c3e54611.1503">   <title>Re: Roman iron and lead </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;c3e54611.1503</link>   <description> Dear sir,<br><br>Thank you for your quick response.<br><br>I guess making a distinction between ancient and modern materials is doable.<br><br>Distinction between Roman en Medieval will be much more cumbersome.<br><br>At least a modern date could be ruled out.<br><br>Best regards,<br><br>Peter<br><br>Van: Arch-Metals Group [mailto:ARCH-METALS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] Namens DAVID SCOTT<br>Verzonden: zondag 1 maart 2015 23:53<br>Aan: ARCH-METALS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Onderwerp: Re: Roman iron and lead [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T10:31:09+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Peter Seinen</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;c3e54611.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;969cbb7b.1503">   <title>Re: Roman iron and lead </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;969cbb7b.1503</link>   <description> Generally Roman bloomery iron could be distinguished from modern by<br>metallography, trace elements, perhaps osmium isotopes and slag<br>inclusions....lead perhaps by lead isotope work and trace elements and<br>perhaps corrosion extent...all the best....Professor David A. Scott<br><br>On Sun, Mar 1, 2015 at 11:27 AM, Peter Seinen &lt;seinen@onsbrabantnet.nl&gt;<br>wrote:<br><br>&gt; Dear all,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Back in 1991 al large tefrite block was found in the vicinity of remains<br>&gt; of the Roman bridge in the river Meuse near Cuijk.<br>&gt; This block contained the remains of an iron O-ring attached in a deep hole<br>&gt; in the block, secured with lead.<br> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-01T14:52:31-08:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>DAVID SCOTT</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;969cbb7b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;2454bcf4.1503">   <title>Roman iron and lead </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;2454bcf4.1503</link>   <description> Dear all,<br><br>Back in 1991 al large tefrite block was found in the vicinity of remains of the Roman bridge in the river Meuse near Cuijk.<br>This block contained the remains of an iron O-ring attached in a deep hole in the block, secured with lead.<br>The O-ring held an iron ring, that left its wear-marks on the block. Its purpose is supposed to have something to do with mooring ships...<br>Although it was found near structures of the Roman bridge as it shows all characteristics of Roman engineering (cut-marks on of the block, the kins of holes for attachment [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-01T19:27:46+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Peter Seinen</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;2454bcf4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;4265192f.1502">   <title>Re: leaded bronzes </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;4265192f.1502</link>   <description> Dear Lorna, There was a question asked by Kunlong Chen on (leaded) bronze alloying in this Group, which may be useful to you. You can find the thread on https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/lists/ARCH-METALS.html - look in the archive under April 2013. If you are looking into the alloying process, and more particularly how to recognise it in archaeological (crucible) remains (i.e., markers you could expect in the crucible slag for different alloying techniques), I cannot think of any literature on leaded bronze specifically. However, I am currently preparing a publication on an assemblage of bronze and leaded bronze alloying crucibles. If this is [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-27T16:14:31+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Rademakers, Frederik</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;4265192f.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;b654d923.1502">   <title>Re: leaded bronzes </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;b654d923.1502</link>   <description> Lorna,<br>what are you after?<br><br>If it is the practical application of how to do the alloying you<br>should refer to casting literature.<br>As a rule of thumb: Melt the most precious metals first, in your case<br>copper, then when Cu is molten add tin and and then lead. This way you<br>end loosing less of the base metals.<br>There is reference to this in the Gie\ufffd\ufffderei Lexikon, but this in<br>German. Contact me if you are interested in that reference. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-27T09:55:59+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Dr. Bastian Asmus</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;b654d923.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item <dc:date>2015-02-27T08:41:41+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Lorna Anguilano</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;453500f.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;7b9b7a1.1502">   <title>Re: leaded bronzes </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;7b9b7a1.1502</link>   <description> Dear Dr. Anguilano,\ufffd\ufffdAbout microstructure of leaded bronzes, there are some\ufffd\ufffdpapers from 2000 to now such as:\ufffd\ufffd- Chinese archaeological artefacts: Microstructure and corrosionbehaviour of high-leaded bronzes, Journal of Cultural Heritage- Uncommon corrosion phenomena of archaeological bronze alloys, Applied Physics A- Combined use of XPS and SEM + EDS for the study of surface microchemical structure of archaeological bronze Roman mirrors, Surface and Interface AnalysisAlso you can see the Prof. Scott's book: Metallography and Microsturcture of Ancient and Historic Metals for some leaded bronze cases.\ufffd\ufffdI wish these would be useful for you.\ufffd\ufffdBests\ufffd\ufffdOmid\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd--------------------------------------------------------------------- [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-26T19:49:43+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Omid Oudbashi</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;7b9b7a1.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;364a6da3.1502">   <title>leaded bronzes </title> suggestion?<br><br>Thank you very much<br><br>Kind regards<br><br>Dr Lorna Anguilano, BSc, MSc, MSc, PhD<br>Research Fellow<br><br>Connect with ETC on Twitter&lt;https://twitter.com/ETCBrunel&gt;<br>T Production debris as historical evidence.<br>*<br>* Dr Elisa Grassi (Universita' Cattolica del Sacro Cuore, Milano)<br>*<br>*<br>* Finding evidence of production in archaeological excavations can disclose new and unexpected insights into the historical and social context of the investigated sites. Places<br>are available, and can be booked on-line, or through emailing the<br>organizers: Simon Timberlake or Fergus Milton.<br><br>*Prehistoric Metallurgy at Butser (Experimental Archaeometallurgy) Course*<br><br>*Friday 3^rd July \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Monday 6^th July 2015*<br><br>At Butser Ancient Farm, near Petersfield, Hampshire, UK<br><br>This is a practical and theoretical short course on the use of<br>experimental archaeology in examining the production of metals at the<br>beginning of the Bronze Age. Through lectures on prehistoric<br>archaeometallurgy and daily practical workshops, the course will provide<br>valuable experience for anyone working in this [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-04T18:47:34+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Simon Timberlake</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;dbf0a6c9.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;f4a721f.1502">   <title>EAA 2015 Call for Papers 'Quantitative and qualitative approaches to prehistoric warfare' </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-METALS;f4a721f.1502</link>   <description> With apologies for cross-posting<br><br>Call for Papers: Quantitative and qualitative approaches to prehistoric warfare<br>Oral papers and posters are invited for the session 'Quantitative and qualitative approaches to prehistoric warfare' to be held at the 2015 Annual Meeting of the European Association of Archaeologists, Glasgow, 2-5 September.
